title: Motion for judgement on to the pleadings the judge granted the planiff which is a credit card company. What do I do?
question: I was sued by a Credit card Company and filed my responds. A date was set by the judge
answers: You are likely too late to fix this. Unfortunately, people who represent themselves seldom get a good result. It is like trying to walk in to a place and try to run complicated equipment that you never saw before. Having said that, you may have some options. Now I have a question. Have you filed bankruptcy and is this judgment from a bankruptcy Judge. If it is the case then, short of throwing a lot of money at litigation that you almost certainly will lose, you may be able to do a Chapter 13 reorganization. If it is a State Court judgment it can be controlled or eliminated. Any way you go, you should contact an experienced bankruptcy attorney, preferably a California State Bar Certified Bankruptcy Law Specialist. You can find them at the CA State Bar website. I have provided a link to the Specialist search for your use.

The judge already ruled for the Plaintiff and time to appeal the judgment has likely passed. As my colleagues have suggested, you are best off trying to negotiate a payment arrangement with the creditor.

This is a question regarding civil procedure. A judgment on the pleadings goes like this. = Hey judge look at our allegations, now look at the defense...if there is not a defense to these claims, then lets not waste the courts time and end this now.

It sounds like the court ruled against you. You should seek legal counsel who specializes in appellate work or civil procedure. That area is not my strong point. I imagine you could file a motion to reconsider or other similar motion prior to appeal. If you exceeded your time limits for a motion to reconsider you could file an appeal - but those need to be filed ASAP too.

Nevertheless, I agree with the other poster that maybe a visit to a bankruptcy or debt relief attorney may be a wise idea as well.
I don't know what your defense was, or it was enough to prevail, anyway. But maybe this is a good time to think of settling the debt with the creditor, before they start enforcing the judgment.
